div3.head:
War Department, Adj't and inst., General's Office, Richmond, March 29th, 1862.
General orders, no. 18.
div3.p: I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
Proclamation:
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the of habeas corpus:

Mr. Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the counties of Green Pocahontas, Bath, Alleghany, Monroe, -cer, Raleigh, Fayette, Nicholas, and Ran- and I do proclaim the suspension of all jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enlisting the Courts to take cognizance of the pre- of wills, the administration of the estates of -sed dersons, the qualification of guardians, counter decrees and orders for the partition and of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridge, to assets county levies and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension with the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties aforesaid.
"In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal this 29th day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two."
"[Signed] Jefferson Davis."

II. Brig.-Gen. Henry Hath is charged with the execution of the foregoing Proclamation.--He will forthwith establish an efficient military and will enforce the following orders: All -illation of spirituous liquors in positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be -ed. The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court-martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th article of War.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
S. Cooper,
Adj't and Inspector General. mh 3t--6t

div3.head: War Department, Adjutant and Inspector Gen.'s Office, Richmond, March 24, 1862.
div3.p:
General orders, No. 16.--All leaves of absence and furloughs, from whatever source obtained, are revoked; and officers and men absent from duty, except on surgeon's certificate of disability, will return at once to their respective commands.
It is with extreme reluctance that the Department adopts a measure which deprives our patriotic soldiers of the relaxation they have so well turned; but the enemy presses on every side, and the necessities of the service demand new illustrations of that noble self-denial which has been so many times evinced since the commencement of our struggle for independence.
The furloughs of all who have engaged for the war, which are thus curtailed, will be extended hereafter, when circumstances permit.
But, judging from the past, no fears are entertained of an unwilling response to this -ll. Those who have so many times proved their devotion to their country, cannot be indifferent or backward in this hour of her -reatest need.
div3.closer:
By order of the President.
S. Cooper,
Adjutant and Inspector Gen. mh 27--6t

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Capt. Wm. W. Parker's Company of Light Artillery having been -ustered into service and secured a battery of -x guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits, if they are of the right sort.
Apply at his office, in the Law Building, at once.

div3.head: Boggs's Battalion of Light Artillery.
div3.p: --As all difficulty about obtaining guns for this command has been removed, I desire to organize my Battalion within the next ten days.
The Commandants of Companies that I have accepted will report to me immediately, and hold themselves subject to an order to rendezvous their commands at such a time and place as I shall indicate.
I wish to secure immediately one good company, composed of new recruits.
Any persons desirous of joining this Battalion, can report to me, or to any of the Captains of my command.

Capt. S. T. Martin, of this city, and Capt. T. C. Leake, of Henrico, are receiving recruits to complete their commands.
I recommend them with confidence, as gentlemen and competent officers.
The former may be found off Bank st., two above 12th; the latter at the corner of Broad's and Brook Avenue.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars bounty.
div3.p:
Attention, Volunteers of Goochland, Cumberland, Louisa, Powhatan, and Buckingham counties, Richmond city, and others — The undersigned, being specially authorized by the Secretary of War to recruit men for the reorganization, for the war, of the old and tried company H, 46th regiment Virginia volunteers, Wise Legion, commanded by Captain Randolph Harrison, of Goochland county, proposes to receive immediately fifty volunteers.
Only able-bodied men need apply.
Apply soon to
div3.closer:
Lieut Peyton Wise,
Recruiting Officer and A. A. Q. M.,
At Beivin's Building, No. 2, 2d floor;
or at Camp Wise, near the Reservoir. mh 26--6t*

div3.head: Attention — Boggs's Battalion Flying Artillery.
div3.p:
The undersigned having authority to raise a Company, to form a part of this splendid corps, for which the most approved light rifled pieces are now being turned out, all those wishing to join a select company, and avoid the militia, will do well to enroll themselves at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
The special attention of the militia is invited to the fact that we are authorized to give the most positive assurance that no man enlisting in this company remains liable either to the present call of the Governor, or to any future draft upon the militia.
Who will wait to be a drafted militiaman?
Apply at the Recruiting Office of the Battalion, Bank street, near the corner of 12th.
Bounty down--fifty dollars.
We refer particularly to Major Boggs's card, calling on those who wish to enter his corps to report to the officers of this company.
div3.closer:
S. Taylor Martin, 1st Company Howitzers.
Alex'r Q. Holladay, Lieut. 20th Regt. Va. Vols.
Wm. F. G. Garnett, Jr., Fayette Artillery.
Richard M. Bolling, Goochland Light Dragoons.
N. B.--None but men of good character need apply. mh12--12t*

div3.p:
I am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished, (this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve months men can re-enlist with me. $50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, under the American Hotel, Richmond, Va. Address me,

div3.head:
Recruits--
Richmond sharp-shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has soon as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 11, 1862.

list.head: General orders, no. 6.
list.item:
II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.
Superintendents of railroads are requested to report daily to the Provost Marshal the number of passengers passing over their roads out of the city of Richmond.

div3.head: Bivouac, near Orange C. H., March 22d, 1862.
div3.p: Deserted from the camp near Centreville, on or about the 2nd day of March, 1862, James E. Robinson, a private in Company I, 1st Regt. Va. Volunteers.

The said J. E. Robinson is about 26 years old, five feet seven inches high, suburn hair, gray eyes, light complexion, and when enlisted was an apprentice to John H. Glaze-brook, carpenter.
He is well known about Baker street, Richmond.
I have been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of Heavy Artillery for three years, or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to confer with captains who have companies, and also with these who desire to raise companies.

"Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered."

Twelve months men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office--Tenth street, three doors from Main City Post-Office, Box 877.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--All furloughs and leaves of absence granted to my men are hereby repealed, and every member is thus notified to report himself at once at Camp Lee.
The company is under orders, and it is actually necessary that every man should present himself for duty.

div3.head: Attention, teamsters.
div3.p:
--I wish to enlist ten good Drivers for my Battery.
To experienced men, I will give $50 each in addition to the Government bounty of $50.
Volunteers now in service, but whose term of enlistment will expire during this month, will be received upon application to the undersigned by letter, at Camp Lee, near Richmond.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 31, 1862.
General orders, no. 12.
div3.p: I. Huckstering in the markets of this city is so great an evil, that it has become necessary to abate it. The whole system is therefore abolished.

The practice of purchasing produce on its way to market is prohibited; persons found buying or selling in such case, within ten miles of Richmond, are liable to punishment at the discretion of a court-martial, and the produce will be forfeited to the person informing against the offenders.
The Provost Marshal will give every assistance to the Clerks of the Markets in enforcing the City Ordinance regulating this subject, and police officers under his direction will attend the markets for such purpose.
All purchases at wholesale in the markets until after the regular market hours is forbidden.
Persons found sleeping in the markets will be arrested and punished by a court-martial.
This order will go into immediate operation.
No hindrance whatever will be offered to country persons bringing produce to this market, but every facility afforded for the accomplishment of such purpose.

II.
The following tariff of maximum prices is established for the sale of produce in the markets, and none other will be permitted this tariff to go into operation on and after Monday, 7th of April, 1862:
div3.closer:
By order of Brig Gen. John H. Winder.
L. R. Page, Assistant
Adjutant General. ap 1--1w

div3.head: $50 bounty.--Crescent Zouaves Battalion.
div3.p:
Wanted--Recruits to fill up the battalion of Crescent Zouaves, under the command of Major W. Hyllested.
A bounty of fifty dollars will be paid each recruit upon enlistment.
A neat uniform of gray cloth, Zouave style, will be furnished.

This corps will be one of the best organized and equipped in the service, and its commander having had many years' military experience, both in this and foreign countries, will make it a battalion worthy of the admiration of his commanding General, and one that young men will be proud to serve in. Those wishing to enlist will apply to
div3.closer:
Capt. Wm. T. Fry,
Recruiting Officer,
No. 5 Exchange Block,
Under Exchange Hotel. ap 1--2w*

div3.head: Headq'rs Recruiting Station 4th Alabama Reg't Volunters, 109 Main street.
div3.p: the following named men have deserted from this station, and the Government reward will be paid for their apprehension:

div3.head: $50 reward for A deserter.
div3.p:
--Chas. Murry, formerly representing himself as Orderly Sergeant for the recruiting office of Lt. M. B. Travis, of the 4th Alabama regiment, and probably claiming to be one W. W. Creath, a recruiting Sergeant, is a deserter from Capt. Thos. T. Cropper's Artillery Company, now stationed at Camp Lee, near this city.
His claim upon the name of Creath is bogus Fifty dollars reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery at the jail in this city.

div3.head:
Captain Parker's
Light Artillery
div3.p:
having been slightly reduced by details for public work from its original number, (130 men,) a few new recruits will be received, provided they can bring recommendations from some one known to the company.
Those now in service, but whose time will expire in thirty days, will be received by application to the Commander, by letter, at Camp Lee.

div3.head: To officers in command of companies.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Secretary of War to organize and to muster into service a regiment of Infantry for the war, I will receive new companies, or old companies wishing to change their regiment at the expiration of their present enlistment.
I shall be pleased to communicate with officers of companies.
I have already six companies.
The usual inducements offered to volunteers.
My post-office is Forrest Depot, Bedford, Va.

div3.head:
Head'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
Special orders, no. 54.
div3.p:
VI.
Recruits, with or without officers in charge, convalescents and other soldiers, now or hereafter detained in this city, for any cause whatever, will immediately proceed to Camp Winder, near the Reservoir, and report to Colonel John C. Porter, commanding at that post.
div3.closer:

Assistant Adjutant General. mh 31--d4w

div3.head: Headquarters Ordnance Departm't, Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is Desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.
Whig and Enquirer copy. mh 29--tf

div3.p:
Our Company of Flying Artillery being nearly completed, those who wish to enter Major Boggs's Battalion are invited to join at once.
Twelve experienced Drivers can secure a good place by applying early at the Recruiting Office of the Battalion, Bank street, two doors from 12th.

div3.head: Curl's Heavy Artillery.
div3.p:
--A few more Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of the above company to one hundred men. The company is now stationed at Jamestown, and is attached to Maj. Wm. Allen's Battalion of Heavy Ariffiery.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid, and clothing furnished.
For information, apply at M. Jones's, on Cary street, or address either one of the undersigned at Jamestown.

div3.head: Flying Artillery.--
div3.p: We are authorized to raise a company of Flying Artillery, to be composed of young men between the ages of sixteen and eighteen, and to be attached to Major Archer's Tredegar (Eighth) Battalion Virginia Volunteers.
The guns we propose to use can be seen at the Tredegar Works.
Each member will be expected to provide himself with a cheap uniform.
div3.closer:
J. F. Goodwin,
Jno. E. Tanner.
Tredegar Iron Works, Richmond, Mar. 24, 1862. mh 25--ts

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120.
An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

Apply to R. B. Pleasants or Henry S. Jones, No. 7, Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr., Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, or Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.

div4.p: --We are authorized to raise a regiment of infantry to be stationed near Portsmouth; and we have the assurance of the Secretary of War that the regiment will be kept near Portsmouth as long as any troops are required for its defence.
We are happy to state that we have every prospect of the early completion of the regiment.
We have established, for the present, our rendezvous at the winter quarter, lately occupied by the Third Georgia regiment, situated near Portsmouth.

Volunteers and recruits will be received at our rendezvous by companies, squads, or singly, and they will be forthwith mustered into service, and be entitled to pay, subsistence, &c., from the time of their being mustered in. Persons raising companies for our regiment may advantageously make our rendezvous the headquarters for their recruits.

Companies now in service can re-enlist for our regiment by having it so designated by the mustering officer on their muster rolls when they re-enlist; and they will be transferred at the expiration of the present term of their enlistment from their present regiment to ours.

Individuals in any company, now in service, can re-enlist for our regiment by having it designated on their muster rolls at the time of their re-enlistment, and they will be transferred from their present companies and regiments to our regiment on the expiration of their present term of enlistment.
Re-enlisted men re-enlisting for our regiment will be entitled to join together and organize themselves into companies, and to elect their company officers.
All persons wishing to re-enlist for our regiment must re-enlist under the Confederate law.
Persons volunteering or re-enlisting for our regiment will be entitled to the bounty and furlough provided for by law.

Organized companies, or re-enlisted men in any numbers, will be mustered in for our regiment at any time, by application to the proper mustering officer, or to Lieut.-Col. J. F. Crocker, who will attend to their being mustered in.

Lieut.-Col. Crocker will superintend the rendezvous at the winter quarters lately occupied by the Third Georgia regiment, and he will be found there or at the Macon Hotel, Portsmouth, at any time.
He will give any information required, and will receive recruits and make immediate provision for them.
All communications addressed to Colonel D. J. Godwin, Suffolk, Va., 14th Regiment Virginia Volunteers or to Lieut.-Col. J. F. Crocker, Portsmouth, will be promptly attended to.
div4.closer:
D. J. Godwin,
J. F. Crocker.
Portsmouth, March 5, 1862.

opener.salute: Capt. R. A. William, 14th Va. Reg't:

div4.p:
I have consented, at the request of the Legislature of Virginia, to accept no more additional companies, battalions, or regiments of volunteers in Virginia, until after the quota of the State has been furnished for the war; but this does not in any manner interfere with authority previously granted to raise companies, battalions or regiments within the State of Virginia.
Any companies, therefore, which may have been, or may be, raised or organized under the authority granted Lieut.-Col. Godwin to raise a regiment for the war, will be accepted, and may be mustered into service in conformity with the terms of that authority.

div3.head:
Howitzer and Rifle
Light Battery.
div3.p: By authority of the Secretary of War, my company will be transferred to the Light Artillery service, and I have secured a splendid Battery of Howitzers, and wrought iron breach-loading Rifle guns, of the most approved patents.
This is the most effective, popular, and distinguished arm of the service.
The Battery will be fully Mounted and Equipped.
A Bounty of Fifty Dollars allowed to each recruit, and thirty Dollars by the city of Petersburg.
Apply at once.
div3.closer:
Jas. R. Branch,
Capt. Co. K, 16th Reg't Va. Vols.,
Craney Island, near Norfolk, Va.
I shall remain in Petersburg a few days to receive recruits
J. R. B. [mh 22--12t]

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a battalion or regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time, and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry, if it can be done without absenting myself too much from my present command.

Persons desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place; or, what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call for the present at Messrs. Yarbrough's, south side of Main street, three doors above 7th, or at my company quarters, New Fair Grounds.

closer.signed: Capt. Comd'g Cavalry Co., P. A. C. S.

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery.
$50 bounty, and
Uniforms furnished.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mail to

div3.head: Headq'rs Elliott Grays, port Nelson, Norfolk Harbor,March --, 1862.
div3.p:
this well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis J. Bosieux, 80 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found at either place of rendezvous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of enrollment, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy response and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All recruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit confidence.

div3.head: Notes of the War.
div3.p: A correspondent of the New Orleans Delta, who left Island No. 10 on the evening of the 19th ult., the fifth day of the bombardment, writes as follows:

div4.head: The bombardment of Island no.10.
div4.p:
For reasons which it would not be proper to make public, I think Gen. Trudeau, who has command of the artillery, aided by Gen. Marsh Walker, of the infantry, will be able to hold the position for some time, despite the circumstances operating against them.
In the meantime, it is to be hoped that the new gunboats from your city will be of some service, and that finally, Beauregard and Bragg having routed Buell, Johnston may be enabled-to regain Nashville, and Forts Henry and Donelson, and Polk Columbus and Hickman.
This done, the enemy's gunboats will have to cease their bombardment of the island, or render themselves liable to be out off. As if they were apprehending something of this kind, the enemy have been moving the land forces which invested New Madrid to Hickman and Columbus, where they can be ready to advance either down the river against the island, or against Gen. Polk's army on the railroad.
One thing seems certain, a heavy blow to one side or the other must soon be effected somewhere in Tennessee.

Whatever the final issue at Island 10, Gen. Trudeau and our army there deserve the highest gratitude of the country for their success and determination thus far in holding that position against the superior appliances of the enemy for its bombardment.
While alluding to Gen. Trudeau, I must not omit mentioning an incident of some interest in connection with the bombardment of the Island.

It so happened that the enemy, getting their boats in position early in the morning, detected a small white flag which was used as a — at Rucker's battery, and was, it might have been supposed, (so small was it,) discernible only to ourselves.
Immediately they dispatched a little tug, like wise with a white flag, to our battery, on the supposition, the officer stated, that we wished to communicate. "Not at all," pleasantly responded Gen. Trudeau, who happened to be there, smiling in his affable way, and adding, "this is altogether a mistake, which will be rectified.
We have no wish to communicate, and hope you will not suspect any under any circumstances." "Very well, Gen. Trudeau," replied the young officer very politely, to the General's great astonishment at being recognized, after having exercised his usual precaution against it by doffing his General's uniform and substituting that of an inferior officer.
The General had gone up to see about the flag, perhaps, or for some important purpose.
He recognized the Federal officer as one who had seen him on some of the truce boats from Columbus.

The enemy must have been more than astonished, after discovering from their boat the character of our battery, by no means so formidable in appearance as it proved to be, and especially after the gallant assurance of Capt. Rucker, added to Gen. Trudeau's, that he was ready for the contest.
They must certainly have been perfectly astonished the next day, with three of their best gunboats devoted to the task, at their utter inability to demolish that single battery, which, as they saw distinctly, there was no harm in describing as in my last letter.
Their whole proceedings since show that they are utterly confounded at the nature of things; and mayhaps they will be even more so when we let loose all our bull-dogs — some of which they wot not of — at their boasted monsters.
Possibly they think the white flag an invitation to examine the battery, and the whole a ruse or sort of cunning device of the wily French engineer's strategy to entrap them.
And here again I must add, it is no business of mine to post them, were it possible.
For all the harm their five days bombardment did us they were perfectly welcome to waste the ammunition, as they did at the rate of fifteen or twenty thousand pounds of powder, besides shot and shell, every day.

div4.head: The Northeast corner of Mississippi.
div4.p: As there is frequent mention of Eastport in the military and naval operations on the Tennessee river, a brief description of the place from the Mobile News, may not be amiss:

q.p:
The boundary line between Mississippi and Alabama strikes the Tennessee river at the mouth of Bear Creek about eighteen miles by the course of the river from the Tennessee State line, through which distance the left bank of the river belongs to Mississippi, the right to Alabama.
Bear Creek is a bold and beautiful stream, well deserving the name of river, having its sources in the counties of Franklin and Marion in this State.
Chickasaw is a small town on the Alabama side at its mouth.
Eastport is on the Mississippi side, a few miles below.

div4.p:
The country in the corner of Mississippi bordering on Tennessee river and Bear Creek, becomes very broken as one approaches those streams, terminating in a range of gravelly hills, either close to the water or separated from it by a swampy bottom.
The latter is the case at Eastport.
The town is a small one, the houses being stuck about in nooks and corners along the street, which zigzags down these hills at such a rate that it would not be difficult in many cases to tess a pebble from the window of one house into the chimney of the one below it. At the foot of the bluff there is a straight stretch of the street, (we do not recollect but one street, though there may be more,) for a short distance, occupied by several stores; but one cannot go far without finding himself in a dark, dank, muddy bottom.
Through this a miry wagon track led some half mile or less to the river, which appeared to be about a quarter of a mile wide, and was bounded by a high, wooded bluff on the Alabama side.
The only object near the river shore was a warehouse, with the marks of the last flood half way up the second story window.
Just below the bluff was a mill of some kind, with an overshot wheel forty or fifty feet in diameter, we forget which.

It would not be difficult for the enemy to make a landing at Eastport, provided they were not molested from the other side, but after landing they would not be able to effect anything if the bluff was held by a few troops of the right kind.
It would be easier to scale a precipice than to climb over those piles of loose gravel in the face of any opposition.
A stream called Yellow creek enters the Tennessee a short distance below Eastport.
Our impression is that it is a sluggish, muddy stream.
There is a pretty field for strategy in the region between Bear creek, Tennessee river, and the two intersecting railroads, and the streams of that region may yet become as interesting in military history as the Rhine, the Sambre, and the Mouse.

div4.head: The Lincolnites in East Tennessee.
div4.p: A correspondent of the Knoxville Register narrates an incident which occurred in Jefferson county, Tenn., on the night of the 22d of March, as follows:

q.p:
Thos. Green, a respectable and well known Southern-rights citizen, noted for his devotion to the South and for his constancy as an humble Christian, was awakened about one o'clock in the morning by some one calling him at the yard fence.
Supposing them to be some of his neighbors' boys, he paid no attention to their calls.
But this availed him nothing.
They continued their calls until he left his room and started to the fence where the calling came from.
On arriving within a few paces, to his surprise he saw four men, one of whom immediately stepped between him and his house and fired off his gun. He was then told that he was a prisoner, and that they were Lincoln pickets, who had come through Wheeler's Gap — that their army had possession of the whole country, and that they had authority to swear in and arrest all men whose loyalty to the Federal Government was suspected.
They then ordered him to take the oath without delay!--This he positively refused to do, at the same time remarking that he was a man loyal to his State and to the Confederate States, and would not take an oath which his conscience repudiated and his patriotism spurned.
He was then told that unless he complied with their order, without further hesitation, that they would shoot him instantly.
One of the cowardly assassins then stepped forward, and despite his remonstrances, forced him to take the oath of allegiance to the negro dynasty.
After administering the oath they left, saying that they intended to arrest all of the prominent Southern men of the community.

div4.head: A capture and a Release.
div4.p: The Tallahassee Floridian, of the 22d ult., says:

q.p:
Col. D. P. Holland, who was some time since taken prisoner with eight men, by one of the Yankee blockading vessels of Fernandina, arrived in Tallahassee on Tuesday last, and left on Friday morning. It seems that after he had been decoyed on the enemy's vessel by their raising a French flag of distress, he was treated kindly by the commander, though his men were put in irons for a time.
On the arrival of Commodore Dupont, Col. Holland, with his men, were sent on board his vessel, where they were well treated.
Col. Holland was conducted into the Commodore's state room, who received him with courtesy, and after spreading a snack with wine and cigars, he told Col. Holland that he regretted his -able detention; that he did not wish to have any question about flags, and that he would send him ashore on a boat, which was done.
It may be well to remark that the Yankee vessels did not pull down the French flag and hoist the American until after Col. Holland and his men were on board, though they had made themselves known as Americans, and upon Col. Holland requesting to return they told him that they thought he had better come on board.

div4.head: Letter from Gen. Buckner.
div4.p:
The Louisville Journal, of the 15th, publishes the following as a letter from General Buckner.
Of course, Prentice could not forego the opportunity of exhibiting as a blackguard, and the "bagged rebel," as he called Gen. Buckner, is treated to an extraordinary specimen of the Journal's characteristic style:

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Louisville Journal:

div5.p:
Among other luxuries of which I have been deprived since my imprisonment, is the pleasure of perusing those chaste and refreshing notices with which, for some time past, your paper has honored me; and although in my progress through the North I have met with many attempts on the part of the press at an imitation of your peculiarly felicitous style of misrepresentation, I have found none to equal the original.
I am, therefore, under the necessity of applying at the fountainhead.
I inclose two dollars, for which please send me your country daily to the following address.

P. S.--Since writing the above, our friend, Col. R. W. Hanson, has reached this celebrated resort, and desires me to add that the present of a demijohn of whiskey, which he learns you have promised him, would never be more acceptable than at this time — the locality and the latitude, as well as the sentiments of our neighbors up the harbor, holding out most tempting inducements to cultivate a taste for that delightful beverage.
As a matter of caution, however, he urges me to add that he hopes, if the liquor be of good quality, you will not venture to taste it, as he might thereby incur much risk of losing it altogether — a privation which, however agreeable to yourself, would be attended with serious inconvenience to himself during the prevalence of the prevailing "nor'easters."

div4.head: The battle in Arkansas--another Federal account.
div4.p: We copy the following dispatch from a late number of the Missouri Republican:

Springfield, Mo., March 11th. via Rolla, March 13.--A messenger arrived at 10 o'clock last night, bringing additional news of the battle.
The engagement took place on Little Sugar creek, five miles this side of a stream of the same name, where the skirmish took place.
On the march down, in anticipation of an attack on the South, Gen. Curtis ordered the trains to be drawn up on the north side, but unexpectedly the attack was commenced on the rear, north of our army, by 1,500 or 2,000 rebel cavalry.
General Siegel, with 800 men, protected the train for several hours, alternately retreating and stopping to hold the rebels in check, while the teams pushed backward to the main body of the army.
While thus engaged Siegel was three times surrounded, but out his way through each time.
The principal fighting on Thursday was done by Siegel in this way. On Friday, the engagement became general and continued so throughout the day. The officers behaved with much gallantry.
The most exposed position was occupied by Col. Carr's division, and the greatest loss was suffered by them.
Col. Dodge's brigade of this division consisted of the 4th Iowa, 1st Iowa battery; 35th Illinois, Col. Phelpis regiment, and the 24th Missouri; 2d brigade under Col. Vandever of the 9th Iowa, consisted of his own regiment, the Dubuque battery, and Col. Carr's regiment of cavalry.

A letter from Col. Carr says the losses in the 4th and 9th Iowa, 35th Illinois, and 25th Missouri, are from one hundred and fifty to two hundred in each regiment killed and wounded.
Only three hundred in the 24th Missouri were present, but they lost twenty-nine killed, and a large number wounded.
The 12th and 17th Missouri, 3d Iowa cavalry, and 8th Indiana, lost about forty each.
Among the wounded are General Asboth, in the arm; Col. Carr, also in the arm; Lieutenant-Colonel Galligan, Lieutenant-Col. Herron, and Major Coile, of the Ninth Iowa.
Besides being wounded, Colonel Herron was taken prisoner.
Colonel Dodge had three horses shot under him. Lieut Smith, of the 2d Ohio battery, was taken prisoner, and, jumping from a wagon to make his escape, was killed.
Gen. Slack was dangerously wounded.
Col. McIntosh was killed Col. Reeves, of the 2d regiment of volunteers, was dangerously wounded.
Col. Hebert, of the 3d Louisiana volunteers, was killed or dangerously wounded Major Gen. Sterling Price was slightly wounded.
Thirteen pieces of artillery were captured by our men, among which was one piece lost by Siegel at Wilson's creek.

Our loss is estimated at from eight hundred to one thousand killed and wounded. The rebel loss is not known, but it is supposed to be from two thousand to three thousand.--Large numbers of rebel prisoners were taken, probably fifteen hundred or more.
They were constantly being brought in. Two thousand Indians were engaged in the battle.
Eighteen of our killed were scalped by them.

Price, with about one thousand men, retreated northward, and then took an easterly direction.
Gen. Jeff. C. Davis is after him.

div4.head: Movements and Indications of the enemy.
div4.p: A correspondent of the New Orleans Picayune writes from Tuscumbia, Ala., as follows:

q.p:
An idea of the enemy's movements and intentions may be formed by the following explanations, which may be understood by the reader if he will look on a map of Tennessee and North Alabama, (and, by the way, nothing is so much needed at this time as a good map of these two States,) which have become the present seat of war. The enemy's approaches may be said to consist of four columns.
First, by gunboats by way of the Mississippi from Calro; second, by the Tennessee river; third, from Nashville, on the Cumberland; and fourth, from Columbus, Ky., and Paris, Tennessee, where a large body of Federals are held in reserve for reinforcements.
The column on the Tennessee river has concentrated principally at Savannah, on the east side of the river, their numbers being estimated at from thirty to fifty thousand, and which it will be seen is nearly on a line with Memphis.

div4.p:
Forty five miles from Savannah, in a southwardly direction, is the mouth of Yellow creek, which is eighteen miles nearly due west from Corinth, Miss., the junction of the Memphis and Charleston and the Mobile and Ohio Railroads.
It being all important to the enemy to obtain possession of this latter point and the two roads in his demonstrations on Memphis, he is now cutting a military road from the Tennessee, at Yellow creek, to Corinth.
Buell's Nashville column has already pushed its advance as far as Columbia, Tenn., and will no doubt march so Yellow creek to support the Tennessee column, if necessary, in its effort to gain the Charleston road.
It is also supposed that the enemy may attempt to gain our rear, by the way of Florence, Ala., on the Tennessee, to this point, Tuscumbia, which is only four miles distant, by a branch road, from the Charleston road.
There is a splendid bridge over the Tennessee to Florence, which could be destroyed in case an effort was made.
Buell's column of 60,000, or a portion of it, might also advance to Florence from Columbia, which is 68 miles; the distance from Tuscumbia to Nashville, via Columbia, by the old military road made by Jackson in the Creek war, being about 110 miles. The great battle must therefore be fought between Corinth and Jackson, Tenn., and between the Tennessee and Mississippi rivers.
Our whole country is thoroughly aroused to the importance of this great battle, and every man has made up his mind that we are not to be whipped.
All feel that we must conquer or die in this battle.
Our forces will be equal to every emergency, and the Mississippi river will hold the slain of the foe. It is stated that the enemy may make an attempt to cross the Cumberland mountains and come in at Chattanooga, but I think attention has been directed to this point as well as Knoxville.

div4.head: A gallant exploit.
div4.p:
A correspondent mentions a gallant exploit performed lately by Dr. Strader, of Captain John Morgan's command, which is worthy of record.
Learning that a large quantity of knapsacks, &c., left by the army of Crittenden in his masterly retreat, was in the vicinity of Livingston, Overton county, Tenn., he procured permission from Major-Gen. Hardes to go after them.
Proceeding alone, in citizen's dress, without even a pocket knife for protection, he collected at different places over 7,000 knapsacks, worth three dollars apiece, and got the people to loan their wagons to haul them to our army.
At McMinville he also secured a quantity of saltpetre and sixty boxes of clothing.
The services of such men are valuable, and deserve to be recorded.

div4.head: Beauregard's call for bills.
div4.p: The New Orleans True Delta publishes the following letter from Gen. Beauregard to the pastor of St. Patrick's Church, in that city:

div5.p: --Your favor of March 14th has just been received.

The call which I made on the planters of the Mississippi Valley, to contribute the bells from their plantations to be cast into cannon, is being so promptly met that I am in hopes of being spared the necessity of depriving our churches of any of their sacred appendages.

Our wives and children have been accustomed to the call, and would miss the tones of "the church-going bell." But if there is no alternative we must make the sacrifice; and should I need it, I will avail myself of your offer to contribute the bell of St. Patrick's Church, that it may rebuke, with a tongue of fire, the vandals who, in this war, have polluted God's altar.
Let me thank you for the expressions of kindness and regard towards myself, with which your letter abounds.
I can only hope that the day is not far distant when peace will once more bless our country, and I shall visit again a quiet home.

closer.signed: Father Mullon, St. Patrick's Church, N. O.

div4.head: The Mississippi Valley.
div4.p:
The Memphis Appeal learns from an officer whose position gives him many facilities for obtaining correct information, that General Van-Dorn is rapidly concentrating his forces, and will immediately move to Pocahontas.
His object is to move against New Madrid, and assist in defending the great Valley of the Mississippi.
It is far more important that we should hold the Mississippi, than the hills and swamps in Southwestern Missouri.

It may not be strictly proper (says the Appeal) to refer to movements of this character, but our military authorities will see the importance of quieting the apprehensions of the people of the Southwest.
We have never participated in the uneasiness felt by many for the safety of the Valley; but that considerable alarm has prevailed in many quarters, which it were well to allay, cannot be denied.
Having arrested the further progress of Gen. Curtis in the wilds of the West; we trust that the gallant Van-Dorn will be equally successful in checking the movements of Gen. Pope at New Madrid.
This intelligence confirms the news received by telegraph from Des Arc, and published a day or two since.

div4.head: More doings of the vandals.
div4.p: A Tennessee correspondent of the Atlanta Confederacy gives another illustration of what may be expected from the villains who pretend to be fighting for the honor of a country's flag:

q.p:
A gentleman who lives near the town of Livingston, in this State, and who is favorably known to parties here as a man of truth, says that a company of Tories from Kentucky went to his house a few day since, during his absence, and drove away all his horses and live stock, destroyed his household furniture, carried off all his beds and bed clothing, not even sparing his wife's wearing apparel and children's clothing, and turned his family out of doors thus entirely destitute.--He gives this incident merely as a sample of what is going on in that vicinity, as many other families have been similarly, or perhaps worse treated.
Many men have had to leave their homes at the dead hour of the night for fear of being hanged, and their families either broken up and scattered, or left to the tender mercies of these ruthless vagabonds.

div3.head: The Southwest aroused.
div3.p:
--By a gentleman who has just arrived from the Southwest via Mobile, we learn that the whole Southwest is most thoroughly and heartily at work — The Mississippi valley is one camp.
The wave is gathering which is shortly to meet and roll back the tide of invasion.
Had the elements of resistance been thoroughly aroused, and the proper machinery sooner set in motion, much loss and suffering might have been avoided.
It is now a matter of time.
The enemy's advance will be stayed and his forces driven back, but at what point is somewhat doubtful.
He may be able to compel the evacuation of Island No.10, or he may not. This will have no serious effect upon the eventual course of the campaign, or upon its final results, although upon the length of time during which that post can be held may depend the extent to which the advancing wave may go. Below Forts Pillow and Randolph the enemy cannot penetrate.

Of further important movements we do not feel at liberty to speak, farther than to say that they are in the right direction, and it is only to be regretted that they were not sooner made. --Wilmington Journal.

div3.head: A good thing.
div3.p:

div3.head: A Delectable Scheme.
div3.p:
The Paris Patric says a British official has expressed the opinion that a settlement of the American difficulties will take place before the first of June on the following basis: The Yankees are to have Tennessee, Kentucky, and Missouri.
There are to be no custom houses along the line.
Slavery is to be extinguished in thirty years. That is to say, the Yankees are to have all they wish, and we are to have nothing; for it is quite evident that they are fighting for this line, knowing perfectly well that subjugation is impossible.
Little do they care to whom the Cotton States, and Virginia and North Carolina, may belong, provided they be allowed to retain the market for their manufactures which they had before the war, and to have free access to our cotton and tobacco, without being subjected to the payment of custom-house duties.
So far as the Yankees are concerned, they would doubtless be glad enough to make such a peace.
But, we suggest, it requires two to make a bargain, and the present temper of the South is such that we see no ground upon which they can hope for such a consummation at present.

This piece of information would not be worthy of notice under ordinary circumstances.
But the source from which it comes suggests a painful suspicion.
Can it be possible that France and England have conspired to force a peace upon as upon terms so disadtageous to us, and so altogether favorable to the Yankees?
After their loud protestations of fidelity to the obligations imposed by the law of neutrality, can they mean to violate it to the ruin of of the belligerent parties?
We cannot believe it possible, and yet the annunciation is calculated to create internally disagreeable sensations on our part.
We are well aware that Lord Russell has been completely Sewardized, and that he takes for gospel all that apostle of lying chooses to tell him. His acts have had so far towards us all the effect of the most active hostility, and the worst of it is, that it has all been done under the pretence of neutrality.

In all history there is no record of any State crime so atrocious as such an intervention would be. Not Catherine II., when she interfered in the civil broils of Poland and ended by taking possession of the greater part of it, was guilty of a more enormous iniquity.
And what would be the motive for such a crime?
Avarice, pure avarice.
The petty traffic of a merchant's counting- house, not any grand political necessity, such as might be expected to govern the actions of a great stateman.
Lord Russell sees the British manufacturers in an alarming state of agitation, and their workmen ready to break out into open revolt for the want of our cotton.
He first makes a bargain with Seward, by virtue of which England is to become the receiver of stolen goods, and the Yankees are to steal it. This plot not promising much, he conspires with Seward and the Emperor of the French to impose upon us a treaty which must result in our ruin; and all from the basest and most sordid considerations.

We have but one piece of advice to give our countrymen.
Oppressed, as we already are, by the weight of a tremendous war, we hope no man will think of submitting even when two mighty empires are thrown into the scale against us. If we are to be hunted like a wild beast for his skin, let us die like the wild beast, fighting to the last.
But first let us take care to baffle the avarice of the sportsmen.
Let us burn every bale of cotton and every hogshead of tobacco.
Let them find nothing when they come to seek us, but steal and gunpowder.
If we are to be crushed, crushed let us be; but let us not fall without giving our enemies cause to remember that we once existed.
Yet it is by no means certain that we shall fall.
As great odds have been encountered before now, and victoriously encountered.
Ten millions of people, fighting for all that man holds dear, cannot be conquered if they will but be true to themselves.
Never, never, let us submit to the arbitrary dictation of nations who have turned a deaf ear to our solicitations, who have taken the part of an enemy against us without any offence on our part, and who have no claim to interfere with us in any shape whatever.

div3.head: Napoleonic.
div3.p:
McClellan, not content with rendering himself ridiculous by his proclamation after the affair of Rich Mountain, is on the stilts again.
His late "order of the day," announcing an advance upon Richmond, is a parody upon the Napoleonic proclamations.
In some places he almost quotes the words of the great conqueror.
For instance, Napoleon says, "it will only be necessary to say 'I was in the great battle, under the walls of Moscow,' to authorize the reply, 'there goes a brave man!'" McClellan tells his Yankees, "when this war is over, we will all return to our homes, and feel that we can ask no higher honor than the proud consciousness that we belonged to the army of the Potomac."

Richmonds as it is in other respects, the first portion of this proclamation is at least instructive.
We subjoin it:

"For a long time I have kept you inactive, but not without a purpose.
You were to be disciplined, armed and instructed.
The formidable artillery you now have, had to be created.
Other armies were to move and accomplish certain results.
I have held you back that you might give the death-blow to the rebellion that has distracted our once happy country.
The patience you have shown and your confidence in your General, are worth a dozen victories.

"These preliminary results are now accomplished.
I feel that the labor of many months have produced their fruit.
The army of the Potomac is now a real army, magnificent in material, admirable in discipline and instruction, excellently equipped and armed, your commanders are all that I could wish.
The moment for action has arrived, and I know that I can trust in you to save your country.
As I ride through your ranks I see in your faces the sure presage of victory — I feel that you will do whatever I ask of you."

While McClellan was thus employing the time which we most generously left at his disposal, we were doing nothing, waiting for France and England to come in and fight out our quarrel, under the belief that cotton was king, and ruled all things.
Was ever madness like this madness?
Was ever folly like this folly?
Did infatuation ever so absorb the human understanding?

div3.head: The Stonewall brigade.
div3.p:
In every encounter of Gen. Jackson's men with the enemy, they have fairly earned the title won by their sturdy and unconquerable valor at Manassas, the "Stonewall Brigade." The late battle near Winchester was another striking illustration of their bull-dog courage.
If Jackson had had a few thousand more men he would have routed the enemy, vast as was his predominance in numbers.
He is a "live man," every inch of him, and so is every man in his army.
We know the men well, and no Spartans or Greeks ever prossessed to tried courage with less pretension.
That common commodity, a gassy soldier, is not to be found in the whole of the common-sense, iron willed, and in every way manly race, who are defending their native Valley.
They are men of marrow, pith, and action.
Fifty thousand suck, marched to Maryland, would free that State, and capture the whole Federal army of the Potomac.

div3.head: The Grentness of England.
div3.p:
It is by her manufactures as much as by her commerce, and by her arms, that Great Britain has maintained her supremacy among the nations.
Whatever the prejudices which the first Revolution left rankling in our minds, embittered though they may have been by the illiberal criticisms of British writers upon America and its institutions, it cannot be denied that, of all the countries in the world, England is the most prosperous and powerful.
If the annals of history record any other country as great, as wise and free, we know not what it is. It is wonderful to think of, that a little island, scarce a speck on the ocean's surface, should attain such world-wide supremacy and dominion.
In that little island is the throne of the world's finance and the world's trade.
The pulsations of the great English heart in London are felt in all the extremities of this creation.
The other nations cannot enter upon any great enterprise of war or peace without borrowing money of the English.
The men from the far East, the representatives of dusky tribes in India and blackamoors in Africa, Persians, Affghanistans, Turks, Greeks, and Arabs, are seen in her streets, brought thither by the interests of their countries, or by curiosity to behold this wonder of the nations.
In her rivers and harbors the ships of all nations, innumerable almost as the waves that bear them, are crowded, her own national flag flying from the masthead of most of them.
The bring to her the products of every clime, and in return she conveys to them their products manufactured into articles of use of and necessity for the whole world.
She exports in one single article of her manufactures more than all the exports of her neighbor France of every kind put together.
And small as the imperial island itself is, the sun never sets upon its dominions.
In the words of Webster, "her morning drum-beat, beginning with the sun and keeping company with the hours, travels around the globe. " Her navy is the most powerful that the world ever saw. All the navies of all the nations of the earth would be no match for the English navy at this moment.
A wonderful nation!
First in wealth, in commerce, in manufactures, in naval power, she is also first in political wisdom, in civil liberty, and, last but not least, in common sense.
She is pre-eminently, the common sense nation of the world; and, in statesmanship, learning, and literature, she can produce a host of names as brilliant and extra ordinary as any other nation that ever existed.
She is the land of Bacon, of Pitt, of Shakspeare.
An island not as large as Virginia, to which all the world pays tribute and reverence!

The example of England must be followed by every nation that would emulate her unparalleled greatness.
It is by diversifying her industry that she has become great, by developing, in harmonious proportions, her manufacturing, commercial, and agricultural energies and resources.
It is upon these massive pillars her structure of greatness rests.
Napoleon called the English a nation of shopkeepers.
But that did not prevent them from conquering Napoleon, and from increasing at such a rate in power that the present bearer of his name finds the chief strength of his dynasty in an alliance with Great Britain.--There never was a greater mistake than to suppose that manufactures and commerce enfeeble the warlike energies of a nation.
On the contrary, war has become, in these days, so dependent upon mechanical arts, that the soldier himself is but one of the various machines employed in its operations, and it is no longer essential that he should possess great physical powers.
The very mobs in manufacturing cities, which are easily dispersed by a file of grenadiers, are converted by military discipline into soldiers, such as followed Havelock in India, or Sir Colin Campbell in the Crimea.
So far as the spirit of chivalry is concerned, that is preserved by the nobles, who have in their veins the old Norman blood, and in their character those lofty instincts of the gentleman, which are as transmissible from generation to generation as the peculiar family features.
There never were in the days of Rome or Greece, or in the most heroic hour of the crusades, a more chivalric class of men than the nobility of England, whilst even among the Anglo-Saxon masses there is an ancient and inherent love of fair play which imparts a touch of rude chivalry to the whole population.

This magnificent and wonderful empire, in which there is so much power, wealth, intellect, freedom, is also a land of law, where every great interest of society is secured; where property is safe, life is safe, and crime is punished.
It is the pride of the South that it is essentially an Anglo-Norman and Anglo-Saxon race.
We cannot do better than study and adopt the policy which has made our ancestors great in their own little isle.
What may not the vast and fertile South become, developed by like energies and spirit?
In agriculture, it has already made the world dependent upon its labor.
But it can never make much progress in power and population till it learns to diversity its industry, and avail itself of its vast natural resources for manufactures and commerce.
That these need not diminish its chivalric temper and military aptitude, is shown by the experience of England, whilst the present war itself gives evidence of the advantages to the North of mechanical skill and resources in the prosecution of hostilities, and really present the most formidable obstacle which the South has to encounter.

Wilmer & Smith's European Times, which appears to be one of the few English papers favorable to the Yankees, expresses the opinion that if the North does not conquer the South in the next ninety days, the European Powers will have to step in, and, for the sake of humanity, both in Europe and America, put an end to the present struggle.

We place no reliance upon the aid of the European Powers.
We can achieve our own independence, and will do it, no thanks to any of them.
As to the conquest of the South in ninety days, that is a beautiful idea.
If it could be effected, it would also be a conquest of the Yankees themselves, and of everything in America in which Europe is interested.--The great staples will be destroyed before they can pass into the possession of our enemies.
We have strength enough, at all events, to accomplish this object, and it will be done.

div3.head:
[Correspondences of the Richmond Dispatch]
interesting facts about the Newbern fight — Cotton burning, &c., &c.
div3.p:
I have gathered some reliable information in regard to the Yankee loss at the late battle near this point.
A letter from a Major was captured by one of our pickets, giving to a friend at the North the particulars of the fight.
This Yankee Major writes, "Our loss was between three and four thousand" A gentleman who has just worked his way through the Yankee lines, told me in Newborn this was the estimated loss, and that one thousand wounded were rent off just before he left.--Our loss was small, not more than forty were killed.

The raid of the enemy into Washington has led to the burning of large quantities of cotton.
Cotton, turpentine and rosin, in this whole country, is so placed that at any moment it may be made food for the devouring flames.
The people of this State do not seem in the least discouraged, and from all accounts they will yet drive back the foe.

div3.head: Fatal fall
div3.p:
--Yesterday afternoon Mr. Wm. H. Martin, a well-known master builder of this city, while working upon some portion of the new building of Mr. Haxall, at the corner of 6th and Grace streets, fell a distance of about twelve feet, from one of the windows to the pavement below, fracturing his skull and breaking one of his hips, from the effects of which death almost instantly ensued.
Considering the height, or distance, of the fall, the result seems to us really remarkable.
Mr. Martin was a worthy man and good citizen, and leaves an interesting family to mourn his sad fate.

div3.head: List of prisoners confined in "Castle Godwin" to March 15th, 1862.
div3.p:
